The target takes 10 ({@damage 4d4}) piercing damage and is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}), or takes half damage and isn't {@condition grappled} if it makes a successful {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw. Until the grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, it has disadvantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws, and that rootlet swarm can't entrap another target.

action.name: Reel
entries: Each rootlet swarm that has a creature {@condition grappled} moves up to 20 feet toward the vesiculosa's main body. Rootlets wander up to 100 feet from the main body.

action.name: Engulf
entries: The vesiculosa engulfs all {@condition restrained} or {@condition unconscious} creatures within 5 feet of its main body (up to 2 Large, 4 Medium or 8 Small creatures). An engulfed creature is {@condition restrained}, has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the vesiculosa, and takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the vesiculosa's turns. When the vesiculosa moves, the engulfed creature moves with it. An engulfed creature can try to escape by using an action to make a {@dc 15} Strength check. On a success, the creature escapes and enters a space of its choice within 5 feet of the vesiculosa's main body.
{@i This glittering pool stands among lush and verdant fruiting plants.}

entries.name: Underground Oasis
entries: A vesiculosa is a huge, burrowing pitcher plant that dwells in oases, spurring nearby growth and luring in prey with soporific scents and tainted water. A vesiculosa's body is buried in the ground, with only its rootlets swarming in the open in ropy tangles. It catches meals with these rootlets and drags them to its mouth. Usually these morsels are unconscious, but the rootlets can put up a fight if they must.

entries.name: Rich Sapphire Heartvine
entries: A vesiculosa's heartvine resembles a lump of sapphire and is highly prized by alchemists (worth 1,000 gp). It can be reached with an hour or two of hard digging.

trait.name: Dance of the Luckless (1/Day)
entries: Vila who dance for one hour create a fairy ring of small gray mushrooms. The ring lasts seven days and has a 50-foot diameter per dancing vila. Non-vila who fall asleep (including magical sleep) inside the ring have disadvantage on skill checks for 24 hours from the time they awaken.

trait.name: Forest Quickness
entries: While in forest surroundings, a vila receives a +4 bonus on initiative checks.

trait.name: Forest Meld
entries: A vila can meld into any tree in her forest for as long as she wishes, similar to the meld into stone spell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: A vila makes two shortsword attacks or two shortbow attacks.

action.name: +1 Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d6 + 6}) piercing damage.

action.name: +1 Shortbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d6 + 6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Fascinate (1/Day)
entries: When the vila sings, all those within 60 feet of her and who can hear her must make a successful {@dc 14} Charisma saving throw or be {@condition stunned} for {@dice 1d4} rounds. Those who succeed on the saving throw are immune to that vila's singing for 24 hours.

action.name: Forest Song (1/Day)
entries: The vila magically calls {@dice 2d6} wolves or 2 wampus cats. The called creatures arrive in {@dice 1d4} rounds, acting as allies of the vila and obeying its spoken commands. The beasts remain for 1 hour, until the vila dies, or until the vila dismisses them as a bonus action.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The vila's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

entries: {@i These beautiful, slim women ride on large deer, their hair the color of spring grass, skin like polished wood, and eyes as gray as a coming storm.}

entries.name: Dryad Cousins
entries: The vila are kin to the dryads. Like their cousins, they serve as protectors of the deepest forests.

entries.name: Demand Oaths
entries: Where dryads beguile to accomplish their goals, the vila coerce and threaten. They demand oaths from interlopers and enforce them fiercely. Vila delight in testing the virtue of travelers and tormenting the uncharitable and cruel with bad weather and misfortune. Particularly obnoxious adventurers might suffer bad luck for months because a troop of vila quietly dances around their camp each night.

entries.name: Hunt with a Pack
entries: Vila rarely travel or fight alone; they are often seen in the company of alseid, wolves, wampus cats, or deer. In combat, they sometimes ride on fleet-footed deer, the better to escape if events turn against them.

entries.name: Vila in Midgard
entries: The vila are servants to Baba Yaga, and she does not deny them. She has many such daughters, an entire nation at her command, though she rarely calls on them. When she does, though, her dutiful children answer her call by the hundreds. They live in the depths of the Margreve Forest and the Ghost Wood, among other places, and are somewhat friendly with the daughters of Perun.

resist.note: from nonmagical weapons that aren't silvered or made of cold iron

trait.name: Close-in Slasher
entries: The vile barber has advantage on attack rolls against any creature in the same space with it.

trait.name: Inhumanly Quick
entries: The vile barber can take two bonus actions on its turn, instead of one. Each bonus action must be different; it can't use the same bonus action twice in a single turn.

trait.name: Invasive
entries: The vile barber can enter, move through, or even remain in a hostile creature's space regardless of the creature's size, without penalty.

trait.name: Nimble Escape
entries: As a bonus action, the vile barber can take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Hide} action on each of its turns.

trait.name: Pilfer
entries: As a bonus action, the vile barber can take the Use an Object action or make a Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check.

trait.name: Shadow Step
entries: As a bonus action, the vile barber magically teleports from an area of dim light or darkness it currently occupies, along with any equipment it is wearing or carrying, up to 80 feet to any other area of dim light or darkness it can see. The barber then has advantage on the first melee attack it makes before the end of the turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vile barber makes two attacks with its straight razor.

action.name: Straight Razor
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Unclean Cut
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature that is {@condition grappled} by the vile barber, {@condition incapacitated}, or {@condition restrained}. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage. The creature and all its allies who see this attack must make successful {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throws or become {@condition frightened} for {@dice 1d4} rounds.

{@i A pale, scrawny fellow clad in a black leather apron and slender ebon gloves grins from the shadows. A maw of needle-sharp teeth and the wicked straight razor at his side are a clear warning that his enemies should hasten their footsteps.}

Vile barbers are sadistic, unseelie fey who move through the shadows to execute their bloody, malevolent wills. Known as barbers for both the use of wicked blades and their proclivity for slashing the necks of their victims, these insidious fey can be found lurking in dark and harrowed places like back-alley streets or abandoned, deep-shaded cemeteries.

entries.name: Fey Punishers
entries: Called the siabhra (pronounced she-uvh-ra) among the fey courts, vile barbers are fickle creatures. They are sent to punish those who have offended the fey lords and ladies, and their cruelty and cunning help them write messages in blood and skin. At the very least, they scar those who have spoken ill of the fey; those who have harmed or murdered the fey are more likely to be bled slowly. Some of these deaths are made quite public—though in a few cases, the victim is enchanted to remain invisible while the siabhra does its bloody work.

entries.name: Slippery Fighters
entries: A vile barber often uses its ability to step through shadows to steal a victim's weapon and use it against its former owner with devastating effect. Any creature grappled by a vile barber is at the mercy of the barber's sinister and unclean weapons—they delight in close combat.

entries.name: Assassins and Envoys
entries: Vile barbers frequently consort with hags and prowl the places these wicked crones cannot go as emissaries and assassins. Some sages speculate that vile barbers are envoys of the Queen of Night and Magic or the Queen of Witches. Information on the siabhra is scant; most adventurers who meet them don't live to share their findings or to see the vile barber lick its bloody blade clean.

trait.name: Green Strider
entries: The vine lord ignores movement restrictions and damage caused by natural undergrowth.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The vine lord has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The vine lord regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point and is within its home forest or jungle.

trait.name: Root Mind
entries: Within its home forest or jungle, the vine lord's {@sense blindsight} extends to 60 ft., it succeeds on all Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks, and it can't be surprised.

trait.name: Spore Sacs (1/Week)
entries: The vine lord can release seeds from specialized sacs on its tendrils. These seeds sprout into {@dice 1d4} green spore pods that reach maturity in 3 days. The pods contain noxious spores that are released when the pod is stepped on, picked, or otherwise tampered with. A humanoid or beast that inhales these spores must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw against disease or tendrils start growing inside the creature's body. If the disease is not cured within 3 months, the tendrils take over the creature's nervous system and the victim becomes a tendril puppet.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vine lord makes two claw attacks and four tendril attacks. A single creature can't be the target of more than one tendril attack per turn.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Tendril
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d4 + 5}) slashing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Awaken the Green (1/Day)
entries: The vine lord magically animates one or two trees it can see within 60 feet of it. These trees have the same statistics as a treant, except they have Intelligence and Charisma scores of 1, they can't speak, and they have only the Slam action option. An animated tree acts as an ally of the vine lord. The tree remains animate for 1 day or until it dies; until the vine lord dies or is more than 120 feet from the tree; or until the vine lord takes a bonus action to turn it back into an inanimate tree. The tree then takes root if possible.
{@i Covered with dark green bark and twining tendrils, this longlimbed humanoid exudes a palpable aura of horror.}

entries.name: Melding of Flesh and Vine
entries: Vine lords are formed from the union of full-grown tendril puppets and the force-grown descendants of plantfolk. Their servants include most plant species, including tendril puppets and vine troll skeletons.

entries.name: Walking Forests
entries: Vine lords seek to expand and empower forests and jungles in the service of their patron gods and demons, or simply to expand their own power. In many cases, they compel trees to walk into grasslands or plowed fields on moonless nights, claiming that territory for the trees.

entries.name: Vine Lords in Midgard
entries: Vine lords owe much of their parentage to the Kijani, the original inhabitants of Kush. They are agents of the Green Walker, working to spread the Living Jungle beyond its current borders. Vine lords marshal jungle denizens to fight for them as tendril puppets, and they often entice druid circles with promises of great power.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The vine troll skeleton regains 5 hit points at the start of its turn if it is within 10 feet of the duskthorn dryad's vines and it hasn't taken acid or fire damage since its previous turn. The skeleton dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate, or if the duskthorn dryad who created it dies, or if the troll's heart inside the dryad's or treant's tree is destroyed.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The skeleton makes one bite attack and two claw attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d10 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d8 + 5}) slashing damage.
{@i These troll skeletons are completely covered in mold and wrapped in flowering vines, and lurk in the shadows of dead tree and profaned groves.}

entries.name: Black Earth Magic
entries: Vine troll skeletons guard duskthorn dryad glades and the sacred circles of druids; others serve the vila or even moss lurker colonies as guardians. In each case, they were created by dark earth magic for a purpose, and that energy empowers great strength and endurance—but little in the way of wits.

entries.name: Constant Regrowth
entries: Their vines regenerate quickly, even after they die. Their powerful regeneration allows vine troll skeletons to reattach severed limbs. Only fire or acid can destroy them and render the living vines harmless.

entries.name: Bound to a Tree's Heart
entries: Vine troll skeletons are direct offshoots of the main vine wrapped around a duskthorn dryad's tree, a treant, or a weeping treant. Vine troll skeletons are mindless aside from a desire to defend their parent tree, and enchanted troll hearts inside the tree provide their power. Destroying the heart at the center of the tree kills the skeleton bound to that heart instantly.

trait.name: Chill of the Void
entries: Kälteschaden, den der Leere Drache verursacht, ignoriert die Resistenz gegen Kälteschaden, aber nicht die Kälteimmunität.

trait.name: Void Dweller
entries: Leere Drachen leben in der leeren Weite zwischen den Sternen und benötigen weder Luft noch Essen, Trinken oder Schlaf. Wenn sie zwischen den Sternen fliegen, gleiten die Leere-Drachen auf magische Weise auf den Sonnenwinden und legen die riesige Reise durch die Leere in einer unvorstellbar kurzen Zeit zurück.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) piercing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage.

action.name: Breath Weapons {@recharge 5}
entries: Der Drache benutzt eine der folgenden Atemwaffen.

items.name: Gravitic Breath
items.entry: The dragon exhales a 15-foot cube of powerful localized gravity, originating from the dragon. Falling damage in the area increases to {@dice 1d10} per 10 feet fallen. When a creature starts its turn within the area or enters it for the first time in a turn, including when the dragon creates the field, must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure the creature is {@condition restrained}. On a success the creature's speed is halved as long as it remains in the field. A {@condition restrained} creature repeats the saving throw at the end of its turn. The field persists until the dragon's breath recharges, and it can't use gravitic breath twice consecutively.

items.name: Stellar Flare Breath
items.entry: The dragon exhales star fire in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage and 10 ({@damage 3d6}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

reaction.name: Void Twist
entries: When the dragon is hit by a ranged attack it can create a small rift in space to increase its AC by 2 against that attack. If the attack misses because of this increase the dragon can choose a creature within 30 feet to become the new target for that attack. Use the original attack roll to determine if the attack hits the new target.
{@i A dragon seemingly formed of the night sky has bright white stars for eyes. Lesser stars twinkle in the firmament of the dragon's body.}

entries.name: Children of the Stars
entries: Leere Drachen treiben durch die leeren Räume jenseits der Grenzen der sterblichen Welt, Wanderer zwischen den Sternen. Sie sind unnahbar und verkehren nur mit den jenseitigen Wesen, die über und jenseits der Erde leben, einschließlich der inkarnierten Formen der Sterne selbst. Wenn niedere Kreaturen die Leere Drachen besuchen, bemerken die Drachen selbst dies kaum.

entries.name: Witnesses to the Void
entries: Leere Drachen sind äußerst kenntnisreiche Kreaturen, aber sie haben zu viel gesehen, da sie sich am Rande der Leere selbst aufhalten. Der Blick in das gähnende Nichts draußen hat seinen Tribut gefordert. Die Leere-Drachen tragen ein Stück dieses Nichts mit sich, und es verschlingt langsam ihr Wesen. Sie sind alle aus den Angeln gehoben, und ihr Wahnsinn ist ansteckend. Er strömt aus ihnen heraus und zerbricht den Verstand kleinerer Wesen, wenn die Drachen in Wut geraten und um sich schlagen.

entries.name: Voracious Scholars
entries: Trotz ihres abgeschiedenen Daseins und ihrer seltsamen Macken horten die Leere-Drachen immer noch Schätze. Edelsteine, die wie die Sterne ihrer Heimat glitzern, sind besonders wertvoll. Ihre Krönung ist jedoch das Wissen. Leere Drachen horten eifersüchtig Fetzen verbotener und vergessener Überlieferungen jeglicher Art und verbringen die meiste Zeit zu Hause damit, über diesen Schätzen zu brüten. Wehe dem, der diese Sammlung stört, denn nichts entfacht ihren latenten Wahnsinn so sehr wie eine Verletzung ihres Hortes.

entries.name: Void Dragons in Midgard
entries: Leere Drachen sind die ältesten Kinder von Veles, der Weltenschlange, und werden von seinen Anhängern als göttlich verehrt. In einigen Geschichten wird behauptet, dass sie die ersten waren, die den Elfen die Magie beibrachten.

entries.name: A Void Dragon's Lair
entries: Die wahre Höhle eines Leere-Drachens liegt tief in der eisigen, luftlosen Leere zwischen den Sternen. Versteckt in Höhlen auf lautlos treibenden Asteroiden oder schimmernd auf den Ruinen einer Sternenzitadelle ruht die Höhle des Leere-Drachen in der großen Leere des Raums.

Wenn ein Drache der Leere sich anderswo niederlässt, stellt er eine Verbindung zu seinem wahren Versteck her. Er bevorzugt hoch aufragende Berggipfel, Täler oder Ruinen in großer Höhe mit freiem Blick auf den Himmel. Von dort aus kann er den Raum durchqueren, um zu seinem in der Leere versteckten Schatz zu gelangen. Diese Verbindung hat natürlich Auswirkungen, und die mächtigsten Leere-Drachen hinterlassen ihre Spuren in der Welt um sie herum, wenn sie sich niederlassen. Eindringlinge aus dem Jenseits und der Durst nach verbotenem Wissen sind in der Nähe ihrer Höhlen keine Seltenheit.
Wird er in seiner Höhle bekämpft, erhöht sich seine Herausforderung um 1, auf 15 für einen erwachsenen (13.000 EP) und 25 für einen uralten Leere-Drachen (75.000 EP).

trait.name: Fed by Darkness
entries: A voidling in magical darkness at the start of its turn heals 5 hit points.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The voidling has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects except those that cause radiant damage.

trait.name: Natural Invisibility
entries: A voidling in complete darkness is considered {@condition invisible} to creatures that rely on normal vision or {@sense darkvision}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The voidling makes 4 tendril attacks.

action.name: Tendril
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d8 + 6}) slashing damage plus 11 ({@damage 2d10}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Necrotic Burst {@recharge 5}
entries: The voidling releases a burst of necrotic energy in a 20-foot radius sphere centered on itself. Those in the area take 35 ({@damage 10d6}) necrotic damage, or half damage with a successful {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The voidling's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 15}, spell attack bonus +7). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

entries: {@i Writhing black tendrils stretch from this indistinct orb of pure shadow. The faintest flicker of something green, like an eye, appears for a moment in the center of the globe and then fades to black again.}

entries.name: Called from Darkness
entries: Voidlings are creatures of the darkest void, the cold space between the stars, drawn to mortal realms by practitioners of foul and corrupting magic known to break the minds of those who wield it. They frequently are summoned servants to void dragons, and they have been seen as wardens of the temples on the Plateau of Leng.

entries.name: Light Eaters
entries: They are said to devour life and knowledge and light itself as sustenance; the places they inhabit are known for their dank chill and their obscurity. Voidlings are summoned by those hungry for power at any cost, and—despite their dark reputation—they serve very well for years or even decades, until one day they turn on their summoners. If they succeed in slaying their summoner, they grow in strength and return to the void. Exactly what voidlings seek when they have not been summoned—and what triggers their betrayals—is a mystery.

entries.name: Cold Tendrils
entries: Creatures of utter darkness, they can barely be said to have a shape; they consist largely of lashing tendrils of solid shadow. The tendrils meet at a central point and form a rough sphere in which something like an eye appears intermittently.
Though their tentacles stretch 10 feet long, the core of a voiding is no more than 4 feet across, and it weighs nothing, darting through either air or void with impressive speed.

trait.name: Focused Animosity
entries: The wampus cat has advantage on melee attacks against any male she has seen employ divine magic or wield a holy symbol.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The wampus cat has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} bis zum Treffer, Reichweite 5 ft., ein Ziel. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) Hiebschaden.

action.name: Yowl {@recharge 5}
entries: Intelligent creatures within 60 feet of the cat who are able to hear its voice must make a {@dc 13} Charisma saving throw. Those who fail find the sound of the wampus cat's voice pleasant and alluring, so that the cat has advantage on Charisma checks against them for 1 minute. The affected characters cannot attack the wampus cat during this time unless they are wounded in that time.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The wampus cat's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 13}). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
will: {@spell disguise self} (appearance of a female human)

entries: {@i A raven-haired young woman rises to the surface of the water as she swims, singing softly to herself—and her lower body is that of a mountain lion. Her sweet song turns to a yowl of rage when she spots prey.}
Wampus cats are all born from an ancient shaman's curse. Trollkin, orc, goblin, and human shamans alike all claim to be able to transform those who practice forbidden magic into wampus cats.

entries.name: Forest Streams
entries: The wampus cat stalks the shores of woodland waterways, using her magic to disguise her true form and lure unsuspecting victims to the water's edge. She is particularly fond of attacking bathers or those pulling water from a stream.

entries.name: Hatred of the Holy
entries: While she prefers to feast on intelligent male humanoids, she holds a special animosity toward and hunger for holy men of any kind. Unless near starvation or if provoked, however, she will not kill women. Indeed, a wampus cat may strike up a temporary friendship with any woman who is having difficulties with men, though these friendships typically last only as long as their mutual enemies live. Some witches are said to command gain their trust and keep them as companions.

entries.name: Swamp Team Ups
entries: Will-o'-wisps and miremals enjoy working in tandem with wampus cats; the wisps alter their light to mimic the flicker of a torch or candle and illuminate the disguised cat, the better to lure in victims, then assist the cat in the ensuing battle. Miremals use a tall story to lure travelers into a swamp when the hour grows late, then abandon them.

trait.name: Standing Leap
entries: The ostrich can jump horizontally up to 20 feet and vertically up to 10 feet, with or without a running start.

trait.name: Battle Leaper
entries: If a riderless ostrich jumps at least 10 feet and lands within 5 feet of a creature, it has advantage on attacks against that creature this turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ostrich makes two kicking claw attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

In the wild, war ostriches are dangerous and skittish beasts, prone to lashing out with punishing kicks while sprinting around the battlefield. The n'kosi use them to create chaos among their foes, by driving a flock of fast-moving war ostriches into a caravan or into enemy troop formations.

entries.name: Faster than Horses
entries: War ostriches have been domesticated for centuries, and they are a fearsome sight on the field of combat when bearing warriors into battle. War ostriches are heavily employed in regions where horses are rare or impractical or where their incredible leaping ability enables cavalry to charge over broken ground.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The water leaper can breathe both air and water.

trait.name: Camouflage
entries: The water leaper has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks when underwater.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The water leaper uses its shriek and makes one bite attack and one stinger attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) piercing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 13}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained} and the water leaper can't bite another target.

action.name: Shriek
entries: The water leaper lets out a blood-curdling shriek. Every creature within 40 feet that can hear the water leaper must make a successful {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition frightened} until the start of the water leaper's next turn. A creature that successfully saves against the shriek is immune to the effect for 24 hours.

action.name: Stinger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage and the target must make a successful {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the creature takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage at the start of its turn. A {@condition poisoned} creature repeats the saving throw at the end of its turn, ending the effect on a success.

action.name: Swallow
entries: The water leaper makes a bite attack against a medium or smaller creature it is grappling. If the attack hits, the target is swallowed and the grapple ends. The swallowed target is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, and has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the water leaper. A swallowed target takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) acid damage at the start of the water leaper's turn. The water leaper can have one creature swallowed at a time. If the water leaper dies, the swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} and can use 5 feet of movement to crawl, {@condition prone}, out of the corpse.
{@i The water leaper is a frogheaded, legless creature with wide batlike wings and a gaping maw. Its shrieks resemble those of a hawk. Its long, sinuous tail tapers and ends in a venomous barb.}

entries.name: Gliding Wings
entries: The creature has no legs or arms, but sports a pair of wide, membranous wings. It uses the wings to glide beneath the water, as well as to soar through the air.

entries.name: Scourge of Waterways
entries: Water leapers plague fresh lakes and rivers. The creatures prey on animals that come to the water's edge to drink, as well as on fishermen that ply their trade in the water leaper's territory. Stories circulate among fishermen of fishing grounds notorious for broken lines and missing bait, and fishermen give these areas a wide berth for fear of water leapers. Desperate or unwary fishermen who ignore the warnings are never seen again; drifting, empty boats are the only sign of their passing.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The treant deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Treespeech
entries: A weeping treant can converse with plants, and most plants greet them with a friendly or helpful attitude.

trait.name: Acidic Tears
entries: Thick tears of dark sap stream continuously down the treant's face and trunk. These tears are highly acidic—anyone who attacks the treant from a range of 5 feet or less must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take 6 ({@damage 1d12}) acid damage from splashed tears. This acidic matter continues doing 6 ({@damage 1d12}) acid damage at the start of each of the creature's turns until it or an adjacent ally uses an action to wipe off the tears or three rounds elapse.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The treant makes three slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., single target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 60/180 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d10 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.
{@i This twisted tree's face is made of cracked, black bark knotted into vaguely humanoid features, and thick tears of sap run down its face.}

Weeping treants clearly are related to other treants, but they are smaller than the normal variety, little more than 30 feet tall with a trunk 3 feet in diameter, and weighing no more than 4,500 lb. Their gnarled trunks are often twisted, and their wood often groans when they move.

entries.name: Forest Wardens
entries: Weeping treants are protectors of dark, shadowy forests, and they are as long-lived as the trees themselves. They act as guardians for an entire forest or for something specific within the forest—they have no pity for those carrying axes or fire.

entries.name: Skeptical Mein
entries: Weeping treants are terrifying and relentless when fighting in defense of their charge. They are inherently distrustful, particularly of anything not of the natural or shadow world, and they're notoriously difficult to fool or deceive.

entries.name: Enchanted Bitter Tears
entries: Sages and scholars debate why these creatures weep, but no one has come forward with a compelling reason beyond "it's what trees do." The weeping treants themselves refuse to speak on the matter. Their tears are occasionally components in druidic spells or items.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 10}). Until this grapple ends, the wharfling can't use its bite on another target. While the target is {@condition grappled}, the wharfling's bite attack hits it automatically.

action.name: Pilfer
entries: A wharfling that has an opponent {@condition grappled} at the start of the its turn can make a Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check as a bonus action. The DC for this check equals 10 plus the {@condition grappled} target's Dexterity modifier. If the check is successful, the wharfling steals some small metallic object from the target, and the theft is unnoticed if the same result equals or exceeds the target's passive Perception. A wharfling that successfully pilfers something flees with its treasure.
{@i Hairless, ugly, and usually dripping water, the wharfling is a nocturnal raider and fond of stealing from fishmongers and jewelers alike.}

entries.name: Waterborne Packs
entries: Wharflings have large, webbed hands and feet and oversized mouths. An adept fish catcher, wharflings establish dens near the shores of oceans, lakes, and rivers, and they often move in family groups of 3 or more.

entries.name: Thieving Gits
entries: Those who have been bitten by a wharfling rightly fear their needle-like teeth, but most coastal communities hate the animal more for its propensity for theft. Their lairs are invariably filled with stolen metal trinkets.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a tiny wharfling. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

action.name: Bites
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 0 ft., one creature in the swarm's space. {@h}21 ({@damage 6d6}) piercing damage, or 10 ({@damage 3d6}) piercing damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer.

action.name: Locking Bite
entries: When a creature leaves a wharfling swarm's space, {@dice 1d3} wharflings remain {@condition grappled} to them (escape {@dc 10}). Each wharfling inflicts 5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage at the start of the creature's turns until it escapes from the grapples.

action.name: Pilfer
entries: A wharfling swarm makes {@dice 1d6} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) checks each round against every creature in the swarm's space. The DC for each check equals 10 plus the target creature's Dexterity modifier. For each successful check, the wharflings steal some small metallic object from the target, and the theft is unnoticed if the same result equals or exceeds the target's passive Perception.
{@i An undulating mass of flesh and teeth, a wharfling swarm is a horrific sight by moonlight.}

entries.name: Bloodthisty Mobs
entries: These masses of hairless bodies writhe along the coast in the moonlight, and often are mistaken for shoggoths or other much larger creatures. Squeals mingle with the screams of the occasional unfortunate fisherman caught in its path.

entries.name: Beach Swarms
entries: Periodically, wharflings congregate in huge numbers and tear along the shoreline for miles before finally returning to their dens. Why they gather this way is unknown, but most locals know to avoid the shore on these nights.

trait.name: Hatred for Spellcasters
entries: The white ape does one extra die of damage ({@dice 1d8} or {@dice 1d10}, respectively) per attack against an enemy it has seen cast a spell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ape makes one bite attack and two claw attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or contract the {@disease arcane wasting|ToB} disease.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Frenzy (1/Day)
entries: When two or more foes are adjacent to the ape, it can enter a deadly battle frenzy. Instead of using its normal multiattack, a frenzied white ape makes one bite attack and two claw attacks against each enemy within 5 feet of it. Melee attacks against the white ape are made with advantage from the end of that turn until the start of the white ape's next turn.
{@i This hulking primate looms over others of its kind. Its filthy white fur is matted and yellowed, and a deranged look haunts its blood-red eyes.}

entries.name: Awakened by Sorcery
entries: White apes were once docile, gentle giants that roamed forested hills and savannah lands. Two thousand years ago, a kingdom of mages awakened the apes, raising their intelligence to near-human level so the beasts could be employed as soldiers and servants, protecting and replacing the humans who were slowly dying off. When the sorcerers died out, the apes remained.

entries.name: Arcane Wasting
entries: The enchantment that imbued the apes with intelligence also bleached their fur white and made them carriers of the {@disease arcane wasting|ToB}, a disease that hastened their creators' demise. The apes are immune to the wasting's effects, but they can pass it to other humanoids. Among spellcasters, the wasting spreads like a plague.

entries.name: Driven Away
entries: The awakening enchantment also gave the white apes a strong desire to serve humans, but because of the risk from the disease, they are viciously driven away from settled areas. They are acutely aware of the injustice that was done to them, and generations of exile have turned their loyalty to animosity, especially toward arcane spellcasters.

entries.name: White Apes in Midgard
entries: In the Southlands, the white apes were created by the mages of the Empire of Morreg. Nearly 100 years ago, the apes were the source of a major outbreak of the {@disease arcane wasting|ToB} in Morreg and Lignas. It has never quite disappeared, and it remains a threat all along the western coast.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Breath of Gales {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon exhales a blast of wind in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that cone must make a successful {@dc 12} Strength saving throw or be pushed 15 feet away from the dragon and knocked {@condition prone}. Unprotected flames in the cone are extinguished, and sheltered flames (such as those in lanterns) have a 50 percent chance of being extinguished.
{@i Howling wind encircles the white- and gray-scaled dragon, filling and pushing its wings without the need for them to beat.}

Winddrachen betrachten alles, was von Luft berührt wird, als ihr Eigentum, und die Sterblichen sehen in ihnen den Inbegriff von Arroganz. Ihr Narzissmus ist nicht unbegründet, denn ihre Ehrfurcht einflößende Macht untermauert ihren Anspruch auf rechtmäßige Kontrolle. Für die Drachen der wechselnden Stürme ist Stärke das oberste Entscheidungskriterium. Obwohl Winddrachen-Wyrmlinge die schwächsten unter den neugeborenen Drachen sind, wächst ihre Macht schnell, und nur wenige ausgewachsene Drachen werden als stärker angesehen.

entries.name: Braggarts and Bullies
entries: Winddrachen gehören zu den größten Tyrannen und schlimmsten Tyrannen unter den sterblichen Kreaturen. Die manchmal tollkühnen Kreaturen nehmen persönlich Anstoß an jeder vermeintlichen Herausforderung und haben großes Vergnügen daran, Rivalen zu demütigen. Sie beanspruchen große Gebiete für sich, kümmern sich aber wenig um deren Verwaltung und betrachten die Sterblichen in diesem Gebiet als ihren Besitz. Vasallen erhalten nur zweifelhaften Schutz als Gegenleistung für unbeirrbare Loyalität. Ein Winddrache kann blutige Rache für die Ermordung eines Gefolgsmannes nehmen, aber es ist unwahrscheinlich, dass er alles tun wird, um den Verlust eines Menschenlebens zu verhindern.

entries.name: Lords of the Far Horizons
entries: Manche glauben, dass die Drachen der Winde viel mehr beanspruchen, als sie zu kontrollieren oder zu bewachen in der Lage sind. Weil sie die Höhe so sehr lieben, ziehen sie es vor, zu herrschen und sich mit den erdgebundenen Bittstellern am höchsten Punkt zu treffen, der ihnen zur Verfügung steht: auf dem Gipfel eines großen Berges oder auf einem hoch aufragenden Monument, das von furchtsamen Sklaven errichtet wurde. Aber diese Drachen werden auch von der Wanderlust getrieben und reisen oft weit weg von ihrem Thron. Irgendwann kehren sie immer zurück, bereit, neue Generationen zu unterjochen und jedem, der ihr Recht auf Herrschaft in Frage stellt, eine tyrannische Klaue in den Nacken zu drücken.

entries.name: Perpetual Infighting
entries: Diese wandernden Tyrannen sind unter ihren eigenen Artgenossen noch territorialer als unter den Erdlingen. Das einfache Eindringen eines Winddrachen in das Gebiet eines anderen kann zu einem Kampf auf Leben und Tod führen. Daher wird ihre Zahl nie groß, und die Schwächsten unter ihnen werden häufig ausgemerzt.

Die Horte von Winddrachen bestehen in der Regel nur aus wenigen wirklich wertvollen Relikten. Andere Drachen schlafen vielleicht auf einem Bett aus Münzen, aber gewöhnliche Dinge langweilen Winddrachen schnell. Während alle wahren Drachen nach großem Reichtum streben und diesen auch zur Schau stellen, konzentrieren Winddrachen ihren Reichtum auf eine kleinere Anzahl bemerkenswerter Trophäen oder einzigartiger historischer Gegenstände - die oft recht tragbar sind.

entries.name: Wind Dragon Tactics
entries: Winddrachen ziehen es vor, in der Luft zu kämpfen, und können dort mit Zaubern und Atemwaffen effektiv sein. Dies kann jedoch für Gruppen ohne Fernkampfangriffe ziemlich frustrierend sein, und selbst dann sind uralte Drachen immun gegen nichtmagische Fernkampfangriffe und erwachsene Winddrachen haben einen Nachteil. Ebenso wichtig ist, dass die legendären Aktionen des Winddrachens und sein Mehrfachangriff beide erfordern, dass man näher dran und im Nahkampf ist. Winddrachen sind darauf ausgelegt, Feinde aus der Ferne zu besänftigen und dann im Nahkampf zuzuschlagen, um ein oder mehrere Opfer zu erbeuten.

entries.name: Wind Dragon's Lair
entries: Winddrachen bauen ihre Höhlen an Orten, von denen aus sie das Land, das sie für sich beanspruchen, überblicken und beherrschen können, die aber so abgelegen sind, dass die Bewohner sie nicht mit Bitten um Schutz oder Gerechtigkeit belästigen können. Sie haben wenig von den Elementen zu befürchten, daher ist eine flache Höhle hoch oben an einer exponierten Bergwand ideal. Winddrachen bevorzugen Höhen mit Felsspitzen und hohen, steilen Klippen, wo der Drache im heulenden Wind hocken und die schwindelerregenden Auf- und Abwinde auffangen kann, die durch die Schluchten fegen und über die Felsen reißen. Für nicht fliegende Kreaturen sind diese Orte weit weniger einladend.

monster.name: Witchlight
languages: understands the language of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Dispel Magic Weakness
entries: Casting dispel magic on a witchlight paralyzes it for {@dice 1d10} rounds.

trait.name: Luminance
entries: A witchlight normally glows as brightly as a torch. The creature can dim itself to the luminosity of a candle, but it cannot extinguish its light. Because of its glow, the witchlight has disadvantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks.

trait.name: Thin As Light
entries: While a witchlight is not incorporeal, it can pass through any opening that light can.

action.name: Light Ray
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 30 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) radiant damage.

action.name: Flash {@recharge 5}
entries: The witchlight emits a bright burst of light that blinds all sighted creatures within 30 feet for {@dice 1d4} rounds unless they succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw.
{@i This tiny ball of bright light seems to emanate from a crystalline center.}

entries.name: Wizard Servants
entries: Also called a "spooklight," a witchlight is a wizard's servant created from a tiny piece of quartz. It appears as a floating ball of flickering light similar to a will-o'-wisp. The hue of quartz used during the creature's creation determines the color of each witchlight's illumination. After the quartz is prepared, it is animated through an extended magical ritual cast under a full moon and a clear, starry sky. Consequently, they are extremely rare by any measure.

entries.name: Flashing Light Code
entries: A witchlight always shares the same alignment as its creator. Although it cannot speak, a witchlight understands Common or another language taught it by its creator. Many spellcasters have taught their witchlights a coded cipher, so it can spell out words by flaring and dimming its light. When necessary, a witchlight can spell words in the air by flying so quickly that its trail of light forms letters. This stunt requires a successful DC 14 Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check per word.

entries.name: Free Roaming
entries: If the witchlight's master dies within one mile of the witchlight, it explodes in a brilliant but harmless flash of light. If it loses its master under any other circumstance, it becomes masterless; it's free to do as it pleases, and it can never serve anyone else as a familiar. The statistics below represent these independent witchlights.

Evil witchlights can be surprisingly cruel, not unlike will-o'- wisps. They seek to lure lost travelers into swamps or traps by using their glow to imitate the light of a safe haven. Conversely, good-aligned witchlights guide travelers to places of safety or along safe paths, and they are prized by pilots and guides. Neutral witchlights exhibit a playful nature—sometimes mingling inside the cavities of weapons, gems, or other curiosities, which means those items may be mistaken for magic items. More than one "wizard's staff " is just an impressivelooking stick with a witchlight perched on top.

entries.name: Witchlights in Midgard
entries: Created only by the star and shadow mages of a few schools, witchlights are precious baubles and rarely seen outside the magocracies or the confines of a wizard's college. They are widely known as familiars to mages of the illumination school of magic.

trait.name: Danger Sense
entries: The wolf reaver dwarf has advantage on Dexterity saving throws against attacks it can see when it is not {@condition blinded}, {@condition deafened}, or {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Dwarven Resistance
entries: The wolf reaver dwarf has advantage on saving throws against poison.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The wolf reaver dwarf has advantage on attacks if at least one of the dwarf's allies is within 5 feet of the target and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, the wolf reaver dwarf can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The wolf reaver dwarf makes two melee or ranged attacks.

action.name: Battleaxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} Treffer, Reichweite 5 ft., ein Ziel. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) Hiebschaden.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage, or 8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.

Like his totem, the wolf reaver dwarf travels in a pack with his brothers in arms looking for worthy challenges to prove himself. Rushing into battle beside his allies for glory as much as plunder, the wolf reaver dwarf throws caution to the wind and fights without care for his own safety.

trait.name: Chilling Howl
entries: As a bonus action on its first turn of combat, the wolf spirit swarm howls, emitting an unnatural and eerie cacophony that chills the blood. All creatures within 300 feet that hear the howl must make a successful {@dc 12} Charisma saving throw or be {@condition frightened} until the start of the swarm's next turn.

trait.name: Speed Over Snow
entries: A swarm of wolf spirits is not affected by difficult terrain caused by snowy or icy conditions.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: A wolf spirit swarm uses icy doom, if it's available, and makes 3 bite attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) piercing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage. The target is also knocked {@condition prone} if the attack scored a critical hit.

action.name: Icy Doom {@recharge 5}
entries: All creatures within 5 feet of the wolf spirit swarm take 22 ({@damage 4d10}) cold damage, or half damage with a successful {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw. Those that fail the saving throw also gain one level of {@condition exhaustion} and become {@condition frightened} until the start of the swarm's next turn.
{@i A pack of ghostly wolves appears in a swirl of greenish fog, seeming to coalesce from the fog itself.}

When a pack of wolves dies of hunger or chill in the deep winter, sometimes the pack leader's rage at a cruel death—or the summoning call of a necromancer—brings the entire pack back to the mortal world as a slavering pack of greenish, translucent apparitions that glides swiftly over snow and ice, or even rivers and lakes.

entries.name: Dozen-Eyed Hunters
entries: At night such a swarm can appear as little more than a mass of swirling mist, but when it prepares to attack, the mist condenses into a dozen or more snarling wolf heads with glowing red eyes that trail off into tendrils of fog. A wolf spirit swarm does not eat, but the urge to hunt and kill is as strong as ever.

entries.name: Absorb Their Kill
entries: Most such swarms serve powerful undead, warlocks, noctiny, or orcish shamans as guardians and enforcers, terrifying horses and henchmen alike. The souls of those slain by the pack are said to join it.

entries.name: Howl Before Combat
entries: Hirelings, mounts, and familiars often panic at the sound of a spirit pack's chilling howl. Packs of wolf spirits are canny enough to always howl for a time before rushing a herd or encampment.

monster.name: Wormhearted Suffragan
languages: the languages it knew in life

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The wormhearted suffragan can make two helminth infestation attacks, or it can cast one spell and make one helminth infestation attack.

action.name: Helminth Infestation
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) bludgeoning damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) necrotic damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or be afflicted with a helminth infestation (parasitic worms). An afflicted creature can't regain hit points and its hit point maximum decreases by 10 ({@dice 3d6}) for every 24 hours that elapse. If the affliction reduces the target's hit point maximum to 0, the victim dies. The affliction lasts until removed by any magic that cures disease.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The wormhearted suffragan's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). It can cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

entries: {@i This humanoid wears robes to hide its corpselike pallor and lifeless gray hair. Fine, arm-length worms wriggle through abscesses in its flesh and its empty eye-sockets. It moves stooped over, with a shuffling gait, belying its speed and agility.}
Wormhearted suffragans are devoted followers of Qorgeth, demon lord of worms, who they believe is the servant and forerunner of a dark goddess of worms and decay.

entries.name: Dark Worm Hearts
entries: Formerly, the suffragans were priests or holy officers of other faiths, but their hearts were corrupted by their fear and loathing. Once pledged to the service of the devouring worm, Qorgeth replaced their hearts with a bulbous, writhing conglomeration of worms, which permits them to carry on with an undead mockery of life.

entries.name: Prey on the Wounded
entries: They frequent graveyards, casting {@spell Detect Evil and Good|detect evil} or {@spell speak with dead} to learn who was truly cruel and duplicitous in life. They also follow armies, visiting battlefields shortly after the fighting is over. In the guise of nurses or chirurgeons, they select their targets from among the dead and dying for as long as they remain undetected. In both cases, they cast {@spell animate dead} to provide the worm goddess with viable skeletal or zombie servants.

entries.name: Fear Light and Radiance
entries: Wormhearted suffragans have a weakness; they are especially susceptible to the flesh-searing power of radiant magic, and for this reason avoid priests of the sun god or gods of light. At night, however, they are a walking contagion, infesting their enemies with parasitic worms that devour victims from within. Their favorite tactic is to cast hold person, attack with a helminth infestation, then animate their slain enemies into unlife.

entries.name: Demon Lords
entries: Dämonische Mächte wimmeln in den unteren Dimensionen ohne Zahl. Uralte Bestien verschwinden aus der Geschichte der Sterblichen, nur um Äonen später wieder aufzutauchen, wenn ihre Pläne sie zurück in die materielle Dimension locken.

monster.name: Xanka
languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Constructed Nature
entries: Xanka do not require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Ingest Weapons
entries: When the xanka is hit by a melee weapon and the final, adjusted attack roll is 19 or less, the weapon gains a permanent −1 penalty to damage rolls, after inflicting damage for this attack. If the penalty reaches −5, the weapon is destroyed. Even magic weapons are subject to this effect.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The xanka's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Absorb
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) force damage, and the xanka regains hit points equal to the damage caused by its attack. In addition, a living creature hit by this attack must make a successful {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw or suffer a gaping wound that causes 2 ({@damage 1d4}) necrotic damage at the end of each of the creature's turns until the wound is treated with magical healing or with a successful {@dc 10} Intelligence ({@skill Medicine}) check. If a creature who fails this saving throw is wearing armor or using a shield, the creature can choose to prevent the necrotic damage by permanently reducing the AC of its armor or shield by 1 instead.
{@i This small metallic globe skitters about on many-jointed legs.}

entries.name: Cleaning Constructs
entries: Created by gnomish tinkerers, xanka are constructs whose purpose is cleaning up their masters' messy workshops. Most xanka are built from copper, brass, or bronze, but gold, silver, and platinum varieties have been seen in the houses of nobles and rich merchants.
Xanka are not built for fighting—their instinct tells them to skitter for cover when danger threatens—but they will defend themselves when cornered.

entries.name: Follow Commands
entries: These constructs only obey simple commands that relate to the removal of garbage. They communicate with each other, but how they do it is unknown.

entries.name: Absorb Matter
entries: When a xanka touches matter with its globular body, it absorbs that matter into itself and breaks it down into energy, so that it can seek out more matter to absorb. Gnomes use them to keep the halls and streets clear of refuse. Xanka can absorb matter equaling half their body size every 6 seconds, but all this absorbing and converting doesn't alter the xanka's size.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The xhkarsh makes two claw attacks and two stinger attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} Treffer, Reichweite 5 ft., ein Ziel. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) Hiebschaden.

action.name: Stinger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Charisma saving throw or have its fate corrupted. A creature with corrupted fate has disadvantage on Charisma checks and Charisma saving throws, and it is immune to divination spells and to effects that sense emotions or read thoughts. The target's fate can be restored by a dispel evil and good spell or comparable magic.

action.name: Seize Strand
entries: The xhkarsh targets one creature within 5 feet of it whose fate has been corrupted. The target creature must succeed on a {@dc 15} Charisma saving throw or a portion of the xhkarsh's consciousness inhabits its body. The target retains control of its body, but the xhkarsh can control its actions for 1 minute each day and can modify its memories as a bonus action (as if using the modify memory spell, {@dc 15}). The target is unaware of the xhkarsh's presence, but can make a {@dc 18} Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check once every 24 hours to notice the presence of the xhkarsh. This effect lasts until the xhkarsh ends it or the target's fate is restored by a dispel evil and good spell or comparable magic. A creature becomes immune to this effect for 24 hours when it succeeds on the saving throw to resist the effect or after the effect ends on it for any reason. A single xhkarsh can seize up to four strands at the same time.

action.name: Invisibility
entries: The xhkarsh turns {@condition invisible} until it attacks or casts a spell, or until its concentration ends. Equipment the xhkarsh wears or carries becomes {@condition invisible} with it.
{@i Watching with many rows of eyes, this mantis creature strikes with slashing claws and recurved barbs dripping with venom.}

entries.name: Dimensional Travelers
entries: The clandestine xhkarsh are beings from another cosmic cycle. Their devices and armor are incomprehensible to—possibly even incompatible with—creatures of this reality.

entries.name: Tamper with Fate
entries: The xhkarsh utilize their fate-altering powers to distort personal histories and manipulate mortal destinies like puppeteers. By doing this, they realign the universe toward their own, esoteric ends—but what those ends might be, only the xhkarsh know.

entries.name: Foes of Skein Witches
entries: Skein witches and valkyries are perpetual enemies of the xhkarsh, whom they accuse of perverting the proper run of destiny for both great heroes and ordinary folk.

trait.name: Ever-Sharp Horns
entries: The ychen bannog deals triple damage dice when it scores a critical hit with a gore attack.

trait.name: Overrun
entries: When the ychen bannog takes the {@action Dash} action, it can move through the space of a Large or smaller creature, treating the creature's space as difficult terrain. As it moves through the creature's space, the ychen bannog can make a stomp attack as a bonus action.

trait.name: Peaceful Creature
entries: The ychen bannog abhors combat and flees from it if possible. If unable to flee, the ychen bannog can attack a foe or obstacle to clear a path to safety. As an action, a driver or handler mounted on the ychen bannog or adjacent to it can make a {@dc 16} Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check. On a success, the ychen bannog moves and attacks as directed by the driver. On a failure, the beast flees. The driver or handler must have proficiency in Animal Handling to attempt this check.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ychen bannog makes one gore attack and one stomp attack.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}27 ({@damage 4d8 + 9}) piercing damage.

action.name: Stomp
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}31 ({@damage 4d10 + 9}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 21} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Destroying Bellow {@recharge 5}
entries: The ychen bannog delivers a fearsome bellow that can be heard up to ten miles away. Structures and unattended objects in a 60-foot cone take 55 ({@damage 10d10}) thunder damage. Creatures in the cone take 27 ({@damage 5d10}) thunder damage and are {@condition deafened} for 1 hour, or take half damage and aren't {@condition deafened} with a successful {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw.

{@i Ychen bannogs are massive, ox-like beasts with thick, wooly coats and great horns like the gods' battering rams. They stand over 40 feet tall at the shoulder and weigh hundreds of tons. Despite their awe-inspiring size, these towering creatures are peaceful wanderers in the wilderness, where their calls echo for miles.}

entries.name: Strongest Beasts in the World
entries: Legends are built on their sturdy backs. Capable of pulling 670 tons (or carrying 134 tons on their backs), ychen bannogs are the strongest beasts of burden in the known world. Tamed ychen bannogs can haul entire communities, or even small castles, and a clever dwarf with a ychen bannog at her disposal can carve out enormous riverbeds, haul enormous stones, or reshape entire valleys with ease.

entries.name: Ychen Warships
entries: Giants have a particular affinity with the ychen bannogs. In times of war, giants sometimes build complex siege platforms atop these beasts, making effective transport for small armies of giants. Thankfully, ychen bannogs are rare enough that even seeing one in an army is a tale to be told for generations.

entries.name: Louder Than Thunder
entries: When riled, a ychen bannog can bellow loudly enough to shatter stones and knock down walls.

trait.name: Ruff Spikes
entries: When a creature tries to enter a space adjacent to a cave dragon, the dragon can use a reaction to prevent the move by flaring its many feelers and spikes. The creature cannot enter a space adjacent to the dragon unless it makes a successful {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw. If the saving throw fails, the creature takes 4 ({@damage 1d8}) piercing damage from the spikes and can keep moving, but only into spaces that aren't within 5 feet of the dragon.

trait.name: Tunneler
entries: The cave dragon can burrow through solid rock at half its burrowing speed and leaves a 10-foot wide, 5-foot high tunnel in its wake.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragon makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) piercing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Poison Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon exhales a cone of black poison gas in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw, taking 45 ({@damage 13d6}) poison damage on a failed save and becoming {@condition poisoned} if it is a creature. The {@condition poisoned} condition lasts until the target takes a long or short rest or removes the condition with {@spell lesser restoration} or comparable magic. If the save is successful, the target takes half damage and is not {@condition poisoned}.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The dragon's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 15}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

entries: {@i Covered in black spikes, the dragon's eyeless head swings from side to side. Darkness creeps from its strange, eel-like hide, spreading like ink in water.}

Als Spitzenprädatoren der Unterwelt sind Höhlendrachen der Stoff, aus dem die Albträume von Kreaturen sind, die sonst wenig zu fürchten haben. Sie können sprechen, aber sie schätzen das Schweigen und sprechen nur selten, wenn sie um Nahrung verhandeln.

entries.name: Born to Darkness
entries: Diese augenlosen Drachen haben lange, dünne Stacheln, die ihnen helfen, sich in Tunneln zurechtzufinden oder Passagen um sie herum zu versiegeln, damit Feinde sie nicht überrumpeln können. Ihre verkümmerten Flügel sind kaum mehr als Fühler, mit denen sie sich in Tunneln fortbewegen können. Mit ihren schmalen Rüsseln stoßen sie in enge Gänge vor, die sie mit ihren Zungen von Fledermäusen und Ungeziefer befreien. Junge Höhlendrachen und Wyrmlinge können fliegen, wenn auch nur schlecht, aber ältere Exemplare verlieren die Gabe des Fliegens völlig.

Die Färbung der Höhlendrachen wird mit zunehmendem Alter dunkler, bietet aber immer eine gute Tarnung gegen Stein: weiß wie Kalkstein, gelb, schlammbraun, dann schwarz bei erwachsenen und älteren Kategorien. Ausgewachsene und alte Höhlendrachen verblassen manchmal wieder zu Grau.

entries.name: Ravenous Marauders
entries: Höhlendrachen sind immer hungrig und bereit, alles zu fressen. Sie verschlingen Untote, pflanzliche Kreaturen und alles Organische. Wenn sie fressen, betrachten sie alle Kreaturen in der Nähe sowohl als Bedrohung als auch als nächsten Gang. Allianzen, die sie eingehen, halten nur so lange, wie ihre Verbündeten sich rar machen, wenn der Drache frisst. Sie lassen sich mit Nahrung ebenso leicht bestechen wie mit Gold, aber andere Versuche der Diplomatie enden in der Regel im Misserfolg. Höhlendrachen verbünden sich auch mit Derro oder Drow und ziehen mit ihnen in den Kampf gegen die Darakhul, aber der Preis dafür ist immer Fleisch, Knochen und Mark. Kluge Verbündete sorgen dafür, dass ein Höhlendrache gut genährt ist.

entries.name: A Hard Life
entries: Da es unter der Erde nur wenig Nahrung gibt, sind wirklich alte Höhlendrachen fast unbekannt. Die ältesten von ihnen verhungern, nachdem sie ihr Territorium von Beutetieren leergeräumt haben. Einige wenige klettern an die Oberfläche, um sich zu ernähren, aber ihre Empfindlichkeit gegenüber Sonnenlicht, ihre erdgebundene Fortbewegung und ihr Mangel an Sehkraft lassen sie in einem schrecklichen Nachteil zurück.

entries.name: A Cave Dragon's Lair
entries: Labyrinthische Tunnelsysteme, Höhlen und Abgründe bilden die Welt der Höhlendrachen. Sie beanspruchen kilometerlange Höhlennetze als ihr Eigentum. Je nach Tiefe ihrer Domäne betrachten einige von ihnen auch die Oberflächenwelt als ihr Territorium, obwohl sie diese nur besuchen, um potenzielle Rivalen auszuschalten.

Große vertikale Schornsteine, gerade groß genug, um die Tiere zu fassen, sind bevorzugte Hinterhalte für junge Höhlendrachen. Die Stacheln ihrer Halskrausen halten sie in Position, bis die Beute unter ihnen durchläuft.

Aufgrund der Knappheit an Nahrung in ihrer unterirdischen Welt kann der Vorrat eines Höhlendrachens zu einem großen Teil aus Nahrungsquellen bestehen: Fledermauskolonien, riesige Käfer, Kadaver in verschiedenen Verwesungszuständen, eine Höhle, die von Kreischern befallen ist, und alles andere, was der Drache nicht sofort verschlingt.

Höhlendrachen haben eine besondere Vorliebe für Knochen und Gegenstände mit starkem Geschmack oder Geruch. Riesige Sammlungen von Knochen, Zähnen, Elfenbein und Schalen riesiger Insekten liegen in ihren Höhlen, sortiert oder arrangiert wie kunstvolle Beinhäuser.

Höhlendrachen haben keine feste Gesellschaft. Sie versammeln sich gelegentlich zur Paarung und zum Schutz ihrer Eier an bestimmten Laichplätzen. Große vertikale Schornsteine sind beliebte Nistplätze. Dorthin ziehen sich auch die ältesten Höhlendrachen zurück, um in Ruhe zu sterben. Man erzählt sich, dass in diesen Felsvorsprüngen, Abgründen und anderen unzugänglichen Orten enorme Schätze gehortet werden.

trait.name: Fire Incarnate
entries: Jeglicher Feuerschaden, den der Drache verursacht, ignoriert den Feuerwiderstand, aber nicht die Feuerimmunität.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragon makes one bite attack and two claw attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d10 + 2}) piercing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Fire Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon exhales fire in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area takes 56 ({@damage 16d6}) fire damage, or half damage with a successful {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw.

{@i The dragon bears black scales, more charred than naturally colored. Cracks between the scales glow a dull red, until the dragon rears its head and roars. Red embers become bright orange flames as the creature lights up from tail to maw.}

Die Flammendrachen sind kapriziöse Kreaturen, die von dunklen Gefühlen und zerstörerischen Leidenschaften fasziniert sind. Die Drachen des ewigen Feuers sind stolz und eifersüchtig, schnell zornig und absolut unversöhnlich. Aus trivialen Gründen richten sie ganze Zivilisationen in Schutt und Asche, doch ihre wahre Motivation ist der Spaß, den sie dabei haben. Diese brennenden Schlangen betrachten Wut, Betrug und Verzweiflung als Spielzeuge für ihr Vergnügen. "Mögest du der Spielball des Feuers sein" ist ein Fluch, der oft von den Törichten benutzt wird.

entries.name: Taunting Others
entries: Die heißblütigen Kreaturen reizen ihre Opfer wie Katzen und sehen die Welt und alles darin als ihre rechtmäßige Beute an. Junge Flammendrachen sind weniger subtil als ihre Älteren. Wyrmlinge können eine Frau dazu zwingen, ihre Familie sterben zu sehen, oder ein schönes Gesicht zum Vergnügen ruinieren - direkt und böse. Wenn der Drache reifer wird, entwickelt sich dieser natürliche Sadismus zu einem Wunsch nach einem komplizierteren Sport. Ältere Feuerdrachen nutzen Politik, Mord und Magie für ausgeklügelte Pläne, die nur ihresgleichen zu schätzen wissen. Viele entwerfen so komplizierte und vielschichtige Intrigen, dass sie keine wirkliche Lösung haben und nur endlose Manipulationen hervorbringen. Ein Held könnte ein Attentat vereiteln, nur um zu sehen, wie der so gerettete König zum Despoten wird. Sie könnte den Wesir besiegen, der dem Herrscher Lügen ins Ohr flüstert, nur um dann festzustellen, dass er eine Schachfigur in einer großen Verschwörung ist. Dunkle Ambitionen, vergiftete Dolche und alte Rachegelüste entwickeln eine solche Eigendynamik, dass ein Komplott beginnt, wenn ein anderes endet. Oft kann selbst die Tötung des drakonischen Drahtziehers das Feuer nicht löschen, das er gelegt hat.

entries.name: Malevolent Purpose
entries: Die Ergebnisse dieser Pläne sind zweitrangig gegenüber dem Vergnügen, das sie aus der Verfolgung eines nebulösen und sich ständig ändernden Ziels ziehen. Einige verbringen Jahrhunderte damit, ein Familiengeschlecht zu quälen, nur weil es das Land des Drachen betreten hat. Andere planen ewige Flüche, nachdem sie schlecht gewählte Worte zu den schlimmsten Beleidigungen verdreht haben. Die Rache selbst ist nicht so wichtig wie ein Vorwand, um zu hassen, zu planen und zu ruinieren. Flammendrachen genießen solche Gelegenheiten zur Rache und betrachten sie als ein reizvolles Hobby. Die Unterbrechung eines Spiels entfacht eine wahre und schreckliche Wut, und in diesen seltenen Momenten der Niederlage kann ihr Zorn katastrophal sein. Ganze Städte brennen.

entries.name: Fond of Souvenirs
entries: Flammendrachen sind genauso materialistisch und territorial wie andere echte Drachen. Jeder verfolgt eine individuelle Obsession, auf die er sich mit wahnsinniger Hingabe fixiert, um seinen Schatz zu füllen. Einige verderben die Unschuld, andere treiben Nationen in den Krieg, aber sie sammeln immer ein Andenken für jeden Sieg, ob klein oder groß. Der eine sammelt verbrannte Schädel, ein anderer die geschmolzenen Schätze gestürzter Imperien. Wenn sie nicht gerade Zwietracht säen, betrachten die alten Flammendrachen gerne ihre Schätze. Jedes Stück erinnert sie an ihre eigene Majestät und Genialität.

Nichts ist vor den endlosen Intrigen und dem Narzissmus eines Flammendrachens sicher. Sie sehnen sich nach absoluter Aufmerksamkeit und ständiger Rückversicherung. Jeder, der einen Flammendrachen demütigt, sollte ihn lieber töten. Sein Überleben sichert ihm über Generationen hinweg die ungeteilte Aufmerksamkeit des Drachens. Noch klüger wäre es, dafür zu sorgen, dass am Tod eines Flammendrachens nicht die geringste Spur der Verwicklung zu finden ist. Alle brennenden Schlangen sehen den Mord an einem ihrer Verwandten als schwerste Beleidigung an.

entries.name: Flame Dragons in Midgard
entries: Flammendrachen stammen von der leidenschaftlichen Tochter der großen Weltenschlange ab. Die Barden sagen, dass ein neues Flammdrachenei in der Welt erscheint, wenn Glaurvistus ihre zyklischen Spiele der Lust und Rache vollendet. Ihre Genugtuung bringt Verderben für den Augenblick und für die kommenden Jahrhunderte, wenn ein neues Ei schlüpft.

Glaurvistus, die Rauchende Geißel, mischt sich in viele irdische Ereignisse ein und drückt der Geschichte ihren Stempel auf. Wenn sie sich langweilt, fabriziert sie einen Skandal und schmiedet wilde, komplexe Intrigen gegen beliebige Feinde, bis alles mit dem Tod endet. Ihr Lieblingsspiel besteht darin, einem unerschütterlichen Helden Bewunderung zu schwören und alle Kräfte in seinem Umfeld langsam, aber zerstörerisch ins Verderben zu stürzen. Ihre falsche Zuneigung gipfelt in einem feurigen Tod für das unglückliche Objekt ihrer Zuneigung. Sie hinterlässt bei der Einäscherung immer etwas, das ihr lieb und teuer ist, und baut ihre Horte mit den Erinnerungen an tausend ermordete Champions auf.

Glaurvistus hat viele Verstecke, die meisten in aktiven Vulkanen oder tief unter der Erde. Jede von ihnen ist mit einzigartigen Schätzen ausgestattet, um Möchtegern-Helden anzulocken. Viele Festungen überlässt sie ihren geliebten Sprösslingen, die das Reich ihrer Mutter bewachen. Es gibt keinen sichereren Weg für einen Helden, ihre Aufmerksamkeit zu gewinnen, als eines ihrer Lieblingskinder zu töten. Legenden besagen, dass sie sich in einem wahren Heiligtum versteckt und die Außenwelt nur durch Magie oder Höhlen aus geschmolzenem Adamantin erreichen kann.

Die Rauchende Geißel erkennt nur wenige Rivalen an. Sie sieht die meisten Drachen als Kinder an und zollt nur den ältesten und mächtigsten ihre Hochachtung. Ihre unmittelbaren Geschwister begrüßt sie mit familiärem Respekt, betrachtet sie aber alle als unter ihrer Würde. Von ihrer Ausgeburt verlangt sie Gehorsam, und ihre Achtung verdient sie sich nur durch ständigen Erfolg. Sie erwartet, dass jahrhundertealte Pläne sofort verworfen werden, wenn sie nur will, und der Preis für Untreue ist eine schreckliche Rache.
Die ältesten ihrer Kinder sehen Muster über Jahrhunderte hinweg, und sie fragen sich, ob Glaurvistus ein größeres Ziel verfolgt, das sie nicht ergründen können. Die ganze Schöpfung ist ihr Spielball.

entries.name: Flame Dragon's Lair
entries: Flammendrachen leben in Höhlen, in denen ein brennendes Feuer immer in der Nähe ist: Vulkane, Schwefelminen, Höhlen voller Geysire und Orte, an denen die Elementarebene des Feuers die materielle Dimension berührt. Was auch immer der Ort sein mag, er dient stets als Schaufenster für alle Trophäen, die der Drache gesammelt hat. Sorgfältig arrangierte und organisierte Preise schmücken die Wände, manchmal sogar geschützt hinter Kristallwänden. Diese Zurschaustellung dient sowohl der Eitelkeit und dem Stolz des Drachen als auch als Lockmittel, um Abenteurer anzulocken, denn Flammendrachen lieben es, die niedrigsten Instinkte in ihrer Beute zu fördern.
Viele dieser Höhlen haben eine große, reflektierende Oberfläche. Ein Flammendrache mag nichts mehr als sich selbst.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragon makes one bite attack and two claw attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} bis zum Treffer, Reichweite 5 ft., ein Ziel. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) Stich-Schaden.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d10 + 3}) slashing damage, and the target loses 3 hit point from bleeding at the start of each of its turns for six rounds unless it receives magical healing. Bleeding damage is cumulative; the target loses 3 hp per round for each bleeding wound it has taken from a mithral dragon's claws.

action.name: Breath Weapon {@recharge 5}
entries: A mithral dragon can spit a 50-foot-long, 5-foot-wide line of metallic shards. Targets in its path take 21 ({@dice 6d6}) magical slashing damage and lose another 5 hit points from bleeding at the start of their turns for 6 rounds; slashing damage is halved by a successful {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw, but bleeding damage is not affected. Only magical healing stops the bleeding before 6 rounds. The shards dissolve into wisps of smoke 1 round after the breath weapon's use.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The dragon's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence. It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

entries: {@i Mithral dragons are wise and learned, and are legendary peacemakers and spellcasters. They pursue their own interests when not called to settle disputes.}

entries.name: Glimmering Champions
entries: Das Licht schimmert auf den glänzenden, silberweißen Schuppen eines Mithraldrachens, und seine winzigen Flügel schmiegen sich an den Körper, öffnen sich aber wie ein Fächer und geben schimmernde, durchsichtige Membranen frei. Sein schmaler Kopf mit den kahlen Schlitzen für Augen und Nasenlöcher endet in einem schlanken Hals. Das schlanke Aussehen des Drachens setzt sich in seinem Körper fort, und der unglaublich dünne Rahmen eines Mithraldrachens lässt ihn äußerst zerbrechlich erscheinen.

entries.name: Rage in Youth
entries: Jüngere Mithraldrachen plündern und brandschatzen genauso viel wie alle Farbdrachen, wobei sie vor allem von der Gier getrieben werden, einen wertvollen Schatz zu erwerben, auch wenn sie seltener zum Spaß oder aus Grausamkeit heraus töten. Im Erwachsenenalter und im hohen Alter geht es ihnen jedoch weniger um materiellen Reichtum als vielmehr um Freundschaft, Wissen und ein friedliches Leben, das sie mit der Verfolgung interessanter Ziele verbringen.

entries.name: Peacemakers
entries: Ausgewachsene und ältere Mithraldrachen sind von Natur aus Diplomaten und Schlichter (manche Drachen nennen sie zynisch Schiedsrichter), denen es Spaß macht, Frieden zwischen verfeindeten Parteien zu stiften. Aufgrund ihrer strikten Neutralität und ihrer Fähigkeit, viele Angriffe zu ignorieren, eignen sie sich von allen Drachen besonders gut für diese wichtigen Aufgaben.

entries.name: Mithral Dragons in Midgard
entries: Mithraldrachen sind rebellische Drachen, die einst versuchten, Frieden zwischen chromatischen und metallischen Drachen zu schließen. Nachdem sie damit gescheitert waren, erklärten sie sich für neutral und suchen nach Möglichkeiten, anderswo Frieden zu schließen - sie sind die einzigen Drachen, die sich gegen den ewigen Krieg des Drachenreichs aussprechen, und sie dienen gelegentlich als Söldner gegen die Mharoti.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: Der Drache kann Luft und Wasser atmen.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: Der Drache verursacht doppelten Schaden an Gegenständen und Strukturen.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragon makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) piercing damage plus 5 ({@damage 1d10}) cold damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} Treffer, Reichweite 5 ft., ein Ziel. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) Hiebschaden.

action.name: Tidal Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon exhales a crushing wave of frigid seawater in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, the target takes 27 ({@damage 5d10}) bludgeoning damage and 27 ({@damage 5d10}) cold damage, and is pushed 30 feet away from the dragon and knocked {@condition prone}.
